data.title: Historical Figures Born on January 21
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays in history for the 21st of January. See which explorers, inventors and historical figures were born on January 21.
data.text:
Charles V 'the Wise', King of France during Hundred Years' (1364-80), born at Château de Vincennes, France (d. 1380)

Johannes Isacius Pontanus, Dutch teacher and historian (1st history of Amsterdam), born at sea off the coast of Helsingør, Denmark (d. 1639)

Adriaen van der Werff, Dutch painter, engraver and architect, born in Kralingen, Dutch Republic (d. 1722)

James Murray, British military officer (Governor of Quebec 1860-68), born at Ballencrieff, Scotland (d. 1794)

John Fitch, American inventor (had a working steamboat years before Fulton), born in Windsor, Connecticut (d. 1798)

Johan Valckenaer, Dutch politician and law professor, born in Franeker, Netherlands (d. 1821)

Tsjalling Hiddes Halbertsma, Dutch Frisian merchant, poet, and story teller (Rhymes & Tales), born in Grou, Frisia, Dutch Republic (d. 1852)

Eliza Roxcy Snow, American poet (d. 1887)

Moses Hess, German-Jewish philosopher, socialist, and Zionist, born in Bonn, French Republic (d. 1875)

Horace Wells, American dentist (pioneered use of medical anesthesia), born in Hartford, Vermont (d. 1848)

1815 John Bingham, American lawyer, politician (US Representative from Ohio (R), 1865-73), and diplomat (US Ambassador to Japan, 1873-85), born in Mercer, Pennsylvania (d. 1900)

John C. Breckinridge, American politician (14th US VP (1857-61 at just 36) and Confederate general, born near Lexington, Kentucky (d. 1875)

Stonewall Jackson

Confederate general during the American Civil War, born in Clarksburg, Virginia

Imre Madách, Hungarian writer (d. 1864)

Ivan Pervushin, Russian mathematician, born in Perm Oblast, Russia (d. 1900)

Oscar II Fredrik, King of Sweden (1872-1907), King of Norway (1872-1905) and poet, born in Stockholm, Sweden (d. 1907)

Sophia Louisa Jex-Blake, English physician and feminist who was one of the first female medical students at a British university, born in Hastings, England (d. 1912)

Karl Staaff, Prime Minister of Sweden (d. 1915)

Ludwig Thoma, German writer (d. 1921)

1867 Maxime Weygand, French general (head of French armed forces during German Invasion of France WWII), born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1965)

1867 Willem Royaards, Dutch theater director (Summer Games), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1929)

Felix Hoffmann

German chemist (synthesized aspirin and heroin), born in Ludwigsburg, Germany [1]

Grigori Rasputin

Russian monk and confidant of Russian Tsar Nicholas II, born in Pokrovskoye, Sibera, Russian Empire

John Lindworsky, German Jesuit and psychologist (Der Wille) (d. 1939)

1875 Paul E. Kahle, German professor of oriental studies, born in Hohenstein, Prussia (d. 1964)

Pavel Florensky, Russian mathematician (d. 1937)

Amang Rodriguez, Filipino politician (d. 1964)

1883 Olav Aukrust, Norwegian poet (advocated literary use of Nynorsk), born in Lom, Norway (d. 1929)

Roger Nash Baldwin, American founder of the American Civil Liberties Union, born in Wellesley, Massachusetts (d. 1981)

Umberto Nobile, Italian aviator and polar explorer (designed and flew 1st airship across the polar air cap), born in Lauro, Italy (d. 1978)

Gustaaf Sap, Belgian minister of Economic Affairs (d. 1940)

Pitirim Sorokin, Russian-American sociologist (Social mobility), born in Turya, Russia (d. 1968)

Cristóbal Balenciaga, Spanish couturier 'The Master', born in Getaria, Spain (d. 1972)

René Iché, French sculptor (d. 1954)

Richard P. Blackmur, American critic and poet (Good European), born in Springfield, Massachusetts (d. 1965)

"Ossie" O.S. Stevens Nock, English railway writer, born in Sutton, England (d. 1994)

Christian Dior

French fashion designer (New Look), born in Granville, France

1905 Karl "The Great" Wallenda, German acrobat (The Flying Wallendas) (d. 1978)

Fred Fehl, Austrian-American photographer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1995)

1906 Igor Moiseyev, Russian choreographer (d. 2007)

1906 John Putz, British journalist (Guardian) (d. 1995)

Nicholas Cayzer, British shipping magnate (British and Commonwealth Shipping), born in Ayrshire, Scotland (d. 1999)

Konrad Emil Bloch, German-American biochemist (1964 Nobel Prize for Medicine or Physiology for work on cholesterol), born in Neisse, Germany (d. 2000)

Erling Persson, Swedish entrepreneur (H&M stores), born in Borlänge, Sweden (d. 2002)

1917 Rohan Butler, English historian (d. 1996)

Geoffrey Dawes, English physiologist (fetal and neonatal physiology.), born in Mackworth, England (d. 1996)

1918 Herbert C. Jones, United States Navy ensign, Medal of Honor recipient, born in Los Angeles, California (d. 1941)

1918 Richard Winters, American army officer and war hero (commanded 'Easy Company' during Normandy Invasion portrayed in "Band of Brothers"), born in New Holland Pennsylvania (d. 2011)

Donald Cuthbert Coleman, British economic historian (d. 1995)

1920 Errol Barrow, first Prime Minister of Barbados (DLP) (1966-76, 1986-87), born in Saint Lucy, Barbados (d. 1987)

Barney Clark, American heart patient, 1st to receive a permanent artificial heart (d. 1983)

1921 Howard Unruh, American mass murderer - shot 13 people in country's 1st mass shooting, born in Camden, New Jersey (d. 2009) [1]

Jean Paul Vroom, Dutch artist and print maker, born in The Hague, Netherlands (d. 2006)

Judith Merril [Judith Josephine Grossman], American-Canadian sci-fi writer (edited influential anthologies), born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1997)

Reynaldo Bignone, Argentine politician and human rights violator, 41st President (1982–1983), born in Morón, Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 2018)

Valentin Ignatyevich Filatyev, Soviet-Russian 'lost' cosmonaut who was dismissed for disciplinary reasons, born in Malinovka, Russia, Soviet Union (d. 1990)

Itzhak Fuks, Israeli El Al captain, crashed in Amsterdam

1933 Joseph W. Eschbach, American doctor (d. 2007)

1933 Norman Willis, English union leader (General Secretary of the UK's Trades Union Congress), born in Ashford, Middlesex (d. 2014)

1933 William Wrigley III, American chewing gum mogul (Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1999)

Max Emanuel Herzog in Bayern, German royal (Duke in Bavaria), born in Munich, Germany

Wolfman Jack [Robert Weston Smith], American disc jockey (The Midnight Special), born in Brooklyn, New York (d. 1995)

Mary Ellen McAnally, American poet (Dance of the Zygotes), born in Vandalia, Illinois

Robin Russell, 14th Duke of Bedford, English peer (Woburn Abbey, Country House TV series), born at the Ritz, London (d. 2003)

Vincent Placoly, Martinique, writer (L'eau-de-mort guildive)

Joseph R. Tanner, American astronaut (STS 66, 82, sk: 97), born in Danville, Illinois

Eric Holder

American lawyer and judge (1st African American US Attorney General 2009-2015), born in The Bronx, New York

Louis Menand, American writer and critic

1952 Marco Camenisch, Swiss environmental activist

Jeff Koons, American artist (balloon animals), born in York, Pennsylvania

Forrest Gander, American poet (Be With - 2019 Pulitzer Prize for Poetry), born in Barstow, California

Kevin Cramer, American politician (Senator-R-North Dakota 2019-, Rep-R-2013-19), born in Rolette, North Dakota

Tyler Cowen, American economist, columnist and blogger, born in Bergen County, New Jersey

Katrine Michaelsen, Gentokte Denmark, Miss Denmark (1984)

Ulrica Messing, Swedish politician

Tsubaki Nekoi, Japanese manga artist

Rick Falkvinge, Swedish IT entrepreneur and founder of the Pirate political party, born in Gothenburg, Sweden

1972 Xiaowei Zhuang, Chinese-American scientist, developed super-resolution imaging method STORM, born in Rugao, Jiangsu, China [1]

Princess Ingrid Alexandra of Norway
